meta.title: New York City Government Structure
meta.description: Simplified graph of NYC government branches and processes for civic education.

nodes.label: NYC Charter
nodes.factoid: The foundational law of the City of New York, defining powers of the Mayor, Council, and other offices.

nodes.label: NYC Administrative Code
nodes.factoid: Compilation of permanent laws passed by the City Council and signed by the Mayor.

nodes.label: Mayor (E. Adams)
nodes.factoid: Chief executive of NYC. Prepares the city budget, enforces laws, and oversees city agencies.

nodes.label: Comptroller (B. Lander)
nodes.factoid: Chief financial officer and auditor of city agencies. Reviews contracts and manages pensions.

nodes.label: City Council
nodes.factoid: NYC's legislative body with 51 members. Passes local laws and approves the budget.

nodes.label: Speaker (A. Adams)
nodes.factoid: Presides over the City Council. Coordinates legislative agenda and committee leadership.

nodes.label: NYC Departments
nodes.factoid: Over 50 agencies and offices implement city policy, ranging from sanitation to education.

nodes.label: Community Boards (59)
nodes.factoid: Advisory groups of up to 50 members each, representing neighborhoods in land use and budget matters.

nodes.label: Borough Presidents (5)
nodes.factoid: Elected officials for each borough who appoint community board members and advocate for local interests.

nodes.label: ULURP (Land Use Process)
nodes.factoid: Uniform Land Use Review Procedure â€” formal public review process for land use changes and zoning.

nodes.label: NYC Budget
nodes.factoid: Annual financial plan allocating about $116 billion across operating and capital expenses.
